item.description:
Referred to by the publishers as a "role-playing party game", Johnsonville: Cutthroat Capitalism is a dice-rolling thematic game set in a small 1950s town.

Players start with a small pool of money that may be depleted every turn, and the object of the game is to have completed the most "citizenly tasks" (objectives drawn at the start of the game) by the time all other players have lost money. Player interference to deplete the money of other players is encouraged.

Actions in the game can be completed in two ways- through rolling against the Game Master, or "Johnson", or by drawing "Kit Cards", fictional cure-all products. Players interact by describing actions and rolling or drawing to attempt to complete them. The positive(or negative) effects of these attempts are described by the Johnson in a humorous fashion based on the numbers rolled or card drawn.

The number 10 is the focus of the game. To score ten, each player has a beautiful set of wooden tiles scoring values from 1 to 3.
The players take alternate turns to place their tiles in the game field. The rows become longer and grow in all directions. Who will be the first player to create a series of personal tiles to score a total of 10?
TEN is a simple, but strategic connection game when players must constantly keep an eye on the opponent’s row of tiles.
Seeing the bigger picture, risk-taking and a little luck are needed to score 10. There are two versions of the rules, so players can test their luck a little more or less.

Bitwy Okretow (War of Ships) is a quick, easy wargame about batlles fought between XVII-XVIII century ships. Players may choose and customize their fleets, creating big number of small ships or small number of the bigger ones. Rules contains maneuvers, wind dependency, boarding and burning enemy ships.

Game was published in the 40 issue of "Taktyka i Strategia" magazine in both Polish and English editions.

Crecy 1346 is a game about most famous battle of the 100 years war fought between Kingdom of England and Kingdom of France. The battle was fought on 26 August 1346 near Crécy in northern France and was the major victory of the English army under the king Edward III.

Game was published in the 40 issue of Taktyka i Strategia magazine, in both Polish and English versions. Is uses Medieval (Sredniowiecze) games mechanic.

Update: Toast! was not funded on Kickstarter, but the design was taken up by Horrible Games and developed into Raise Your Goblets.

Toast! is themed around ruthless medieval nobles trying to poison each other during the toasts at a royal function. The King has decreed a bizarre etiquette to be followed, in an attempt to discourage this behaviour. However, instead it has just turned the practice into an art and a sport, with each (surviving) noble having developed a particular expertise.

In a round of play, goblets are arranged in a circle in the middle of the table, one in front of each player, such that players can’t see their contents. Players take turns to secretly place wine, poison or antidote tokens into the goblets, switching the goblets around, or using their characters special abilities. Each player has a target, and their aim is to ensure that, when the round is ended by someone calling for the Toast and the players all ‘drink’, their target’s goblet is poisoned and theirs is safe!

The game supports 2-12 players. The main rules are for 4-6 players, there are special rules to extend up to 12 players (where pairs of players play as a noble and their wine-taster), and there is a separate game mode for 2-3 players (a sort of Russian Roulette with goblets).

item.description:
How much of what you say is actually made up of your words?

Emotional IQ is a hilarious new party game for 2 players on up to party size groups. It’s easy to learn and easy to play. There are 2 types of cards: the Emotion Cards, and the Sentence Cards. You’ll choose 1 card from each stack and then deliver the sentence aloud for everyone to hear.

How do you say, “Great news everyone, I got engaged today” in your best sad voice? ...or... "That guy just sneezed all over you" in a voice full of Happiness?

Other players will have to guess which Emotion you are using. Here’s the catch – no one except you knows which Emotion card you drew, the Sentence and Emotion rarely match, and you only get 1 shot at your delivery.

It's a science experiment of your brain vs your mouth. Emotional IQ is designed by Bryan Sloan and illustrated by Roman Shipunov.

item.description:
1916, Europe: The Great War has ravaged the land. Only one fertile ground remains and it is strongly disputed...by moles?

In Topoum, you control an army of moles that are fighting for control of a piece of fertile land in the middle of the Great War. The moles are well known for their blindness and, for this reason, you'll earn badges (points) if you can form uninterrupted lines of sight between your soldiers.

Topoum features several different types of cards of four categories: combat, movement, expansion and special. Each game is different because you build the playing deck with seven types of cards (+110.000 combinations!).

Each player has a private hand with two cards and there is a public row of five cards available for all the players on the board. This is the structure of the turn:


 Choose between "Enter the Battle with a Mole" (playing one card is mandatory) or "Move Moles in the Battlefield" (playing a card is optional for each mole).
 Score the lines of sight between your moles.
 Refill the cards in your hand and the public row.


When the "Peace" card (hidden at the bottom part of the deck) is drawn, the game ends. The players now score extra badges for majorities and sets of the categories of the cards they used during the battle.

name.value: '65: Squad-Level Combat in the Jungles of Vietnam

item.description:
A squad-level, tactical game, ’65 recounts the early battles of the Vietnam War, from Ia Drang to Operation Starlight, and most everything between. The large and beautiful counters (1" to 1.375" square) represent squads, Leaders, Heroes, Snipers, M-48 and Pt-76 tanks, and more.

As these units’ commander you will move and fight over three geomorphic game boards as you try to best your opponent in one of eight, nail-biting historical scenarios. The game is card-driven, using a system similar to Flying Pig’s Night of Man, which adds a sense of delicious uncertainty to the play. “Can I advance my sappers or does the enemy have a fire card he's just waiting to play?" Furthermore, the cards simplify the game, containing much of the data needed to play. You won’t spend the afternoon with your head in a rule book when you play ’65. This is a game created by gamers for gamers to play.

Each Game Includes:

 3 richly illustrated, 11” x 17” geomorphic game boards.
 Over 175 HUGE 1” and 1.375” counters.
 1 deck of 54 action cards.
 Full color rules and scenario booklet.




(from the publisher's website)

You move your pawn on a wooden board that look like a spider web and where you can go in any direction and where you can only play one dice at a time. Your goal is to move your pawn to go reach the square that matches your cards in your hand.

When you reach the square of one of your card you can remove this card from your hand :)

item.description:
999 Games made this 25th anniversary gift pack in 2015. When purchasing any game by 999 Games, you would receive this as a gift.

It contains the following items:
- a mini-expansion for Catan (Catan: 999 Games 25 jaar Expansion)
- a try-out game of Carcassonne
- a mini game of SET
- a promo game of Ghost Blitz
- a try-out game of Absacker
- a (cardboard) try-out game of Qwirkle
- a 54 piece puzzle
- cash-back coupon book for all of the above

The box has the text "999 Games trakteert!" on it, which mean "999 Games treats!", as in a birthday treat.

In MountTen (ãƒ†ãƒ³ã‚¬ãƒ­ãƒ³), players want to rid themselves of cards in hand first in order to win the round. The deck consists of green cards numbered 1-40 and red cards numbered 10-30. Players start with ten cards in hand with 2-3 players and eight cards with 4-6 players. Set the deck nearby with the top card revealed.

The start player plays any card to the center of the table. The next player must play a card at most ten lower or higher than this card, e.g., playing 14-34 if the 24 was lead. If the second-played card is lower (higher), then all subsequent cards must be lower (higher) — but also always within ten of the most recently played card. If a player cannot or doesn't want to play, they pass and draw the top card of the deck, then reveal the new top card. If all players pass in turn, then whoever played the most recent card clears the table and leads a new card.

Two exceptions:

1. If the next player in turn can play a green card exactly ten lower or higher than the topmost card on the pile (no matter the direction of play), that player can call "Mount Ten!", play the card, then clear the table and lead a new card.

2. If any player can play a red card exactly ten lower or higher than the topmost card on the pile (no matter the direction of play), that player can call "Mount Ten!", play the card, then clear the table and lead a new card.

When one player has no cards in hand, the round ends. Each player with cards in hand scores -1 for each green card and -2 for each red card; the player who went out scores positive points equal to all the negative points scored that round. Complete as many rounds as the number of players, with the start player rotating each round. Whoever then has the highest score wins!

link.value: テンデイズゲームズ (Ten Days Games)

item.description:
In Brides and Bribes, a strategy game played over six rounds, each player takes the role of a powerful family of Genoa. Carefully employing your family members, each of whom has a unique ability, is the key to your success.

Each round, you plan send your family members to the Genoese boroughs to hire new employees, get new workers, and convince the local lord that your family is worth a marriage with his beautiful daughter. If you want to succeed, you have to send the right person in the right place.

Hire the most skilled people, intermarry with the most powerful families, poison your enemies, and increase your commercial empire!

item.description: Game is played on a large plastic floor mat. Comes with large plastic dice and four small troll dolls for playing pieces. Game board and play is similar to Candyland with bridges that can be used for shortcuts. Winner is the first to reach the castle.

Global War 1936-1945 Second Edition is the re-implementation of Global War 1939, which is its First Edition iteration. This Second Edition is a remastered version of Global 1939, with the scope of the game greatly expanded. Here are some of the key points:

There are a lot of rules in Global War -2nd edition but do not be intimidated! Many of them are optional and you are encouraged to select rules that suit the type of play you enjoy. New rules in this expansion include:

 Multi-stage ship and facility production
 Advanced research development system with 13 technologies.
 Nation-specific victory objectives
 New Lend-lease system where players can lend money or units.
 Soviet Union as a third alliance
 Spanish Civil War
 Chinese Civil War
 Advanced convoy raiding system with world-wide convoy routes and escorts
 New units including airborne infantry, militia, cavalry, mountain infantry, marines, medium bombers, coastal submarines (and more)
 Carpet Bombing
 Combat Air Patrol
 Diplomatic Pacts
 Strategic Rail Movement
 New facilities: Shipyards, coastal artillery, fortifications (and more)




The new map is completely redone with more territories and land features than ever. These include;

 Mountains
 Rivers
 Baltic-White Sea Canal
 Minor power colonies
 New nations
 Chinese Warlord Regions




Global War-2nd Edition is already the most expanded game of its genre. Expansions include:
• Fighting Railways
• U.S. & German Ordnance
• Amerika Companion
• United States Unit Set #3
• The Few the Proud, The Marines
• Alaskan Warriors
• Over 30 3D Printed Game Units

A handicap system is also provided so that two players with uneven skills can still enjoy the game

At the end of the game, the player with the lowest overall scoring line (based on the four lines each player owns) loses the game.

name.value: Enemy Coast Ahead: The Doolittle Raid

item.description:
Enemy Coast Ahead: The Doolittle Raid uses the game format to explore the first raid on the Japanese home islands by the United States during World War Two. It is a solitaire game challenging the player to conduct a successful mission where the criteria for success is not purely military. The player must organize, equip, and train a squadron of B-25 medium “Mitchell” bombers to attack a distant and rather dangerous target. The game not only covers the raid from launch to landing, it extends the story on both ends. Threatened from the air and from the sea, the player must do his utmost to strike the Japanese capital, avenging the attack on Pearl Harbor, and then land his aircraft safely. If the raid goes poorly it may boost Japanese morale and deflate the mood in the United States. Getting the B-25s close enough to launch is vital, as is the recovery of aircraft and crewmen, but above all, the player’s main dilemma will be secrecy. The risk is great. Failure could mean the loss of an entire squadron, or worse, the sinking of a precious aircraft carrier. Will the Doolittle Raid add to the dismal news of Pearl Harbor, Guam, Wake Island, and Bataan, or will it signal the turning of the tide?

The History
Washington – April 21, 1942: After two days of rumor prompted by Japanese radio broadcasts, President Franklin Delano Roosevelt finally agrees to a press conference. Deftly avoiding difficult questions, he claims insufficient information to neither confirm nor deny the biggest news story of the four month old war. To placate tenacious journalists, however, he tells the press that the attack on Kobe, Osaka, Nagoya, and Tokyo by United States aircraft, was launched from a mysterious base he would only call “Shangri-La,” an imaginary island from the recently published novel Lost Horizon. His impish grin, if not his words, tell the press that the top secret operation dubbed Special Aviation Project Number One has indeed been a success.

That same day China’s foreign minister hands a telegram to Army Air Corps Chief Hap Arnold. It has taken some time to arrive in Washington, an indication that all may not be well with the mission. Dictated two days ago by the commander of that top secret operation, a distraught Lt. Colonel James Doolittle, it reads:

Mission to bomb Tokyo has been accomplished. On entering China we ran into bad weather and it is feared that all planes crashed.

Telegram in hand, Arnold immediately admits to the commander of the Joint Chiefs of Staff that the mission has failed. No bombers have been recovered. After sending that telegram, Doolittle himself expects a court marshall, confiding to his engineer that they’ll tie him to a desk for the rest of the war, if he’s lucky. Days later he is astonished to learn of his promotion to Brigadier General, and even more so when he is notified that the president recommended the Congressional Medal of Honor.

The Doolittle Raid remains an enigmatic and contradictory episode of World War Two, defying easy interpretation even to this day. Was it a victory or a debacle? Was it a minor footnote in the annals of that war or a significant military event? Was it a desperate bid to avenge the attack on Pearl Harbor, or, a harbinger signaling death and horror soon to visit Japanese cities from the sky?

Narrative Sequence
Much like chapters in a story, the game is organized in six narrative segments, chronologically arranged. Each poses its own set of challenges and prompts decisions that establish the environment and conditions of subsequent chapters.

Planning
Naval
Flight
Over Targets
Recovery
Debriefing

Historical Scenarios
Besides play of the full narrative, the game offers a number of historical dissections, each a scenario focusing on a fragment of the raid. They are also a handy way to learn the game, since each scenario uses only part of the rules. For example, Scenario One covers Doolittle’s flight over Tokyo, using only the 8.5x11 Target Map and the Attack Segment. An alternative scenario looks at a night raid by that flight, as Doolittle originally planned it. After playing one or two small scenarios using only the Attack segment’s rules, a larger scenario can be played adding the Flight segment. Graduate next to an even larger scenario that starts with the Naval segment. In this way a player can learn the game in program fashion, little by little, studying the history of the raid by playing it as he learns.

Player Aid Folders: The game comes with several 11” x 17” bi-fold aids allowing the play of each game segment with minimal study of the rule book. The mapsheet is designed to interlock with other game components, including those play aids, in order to make the player’s experience fluid.

item.description:
A new epic fighting card game to experience! Build your own fighter, complete with weapons, armor, masteries and origin stories and fight to see who built the best one! Karacterz features 77 unique artworks of 63 artists from 23 countries. Play with a fresh experience every time.

Build your character to specialize in either Magical, Agility (martial arts) or Physical (medieval warfare), have a combination of two of them or all three! Players also build up their character's combat deck to fight with and buff them up with stats. There is no Life Points or Maximum Health in Karacterz so deal as much damage to your opponents as possible! Player with the least amount of damage on them is the victor.

Karacterz is a great game for gamers of all styles and skill levels. This is a perfect game for skilled gamers to play with more casual gamers. Karacterz features many small game mechanics that interact with each other, perfect for experienced gamers, but not necessary a must to win. Those who find the depth of Karacterz overwhelming need not play with every feature to have a great time and beat up their friends!

Playing with a large group? Karacterz features a Teamwork/Betrayal system that guarantees to make group play interesting and more fun! Wanna check out more about Karacterz? Go to our links!

item.description:
Welcome to your last semester of college!
 Dropout is a humorous take-that card game for up to four players who try to raise their G.P.A in order to graduate.

Unfortunately, there are so many distractions to your studies: parties to attend, movies to watch and beer to drink. Each one of these distractions will lower your G.P.A. However, if you study, do your homework and avoid temptation, you might be able to raise and your G.P.A and graduate!

Each turn players will place activity cards to increase their G.P.A and distraction cards on the other players to lower theirs. After four rounds of triumphs and defeats, one semester has passed.

Earn the highest G.P.A in four semesters and become the one who doesn't Dropout

Welcome to Robert Houdin’s theater! The most famous magicians in the world come here to prove themselves. You will have to show your skills in card, coin and stage magic. Will you gain the audience’s favor or will this be your last performance?

Alakazam! is a fast-paced card game for 2 to 6 players. Players are dealt a hand of cards with a set of three magic tricks in each. In every turn, each player has to play a card that has a better trick than the one performed by the previous player. They must pass if they don't have a card with a better trick.

The first player to perform all his tricks wins the game.

You always suspected that they were psycho, now it is time to prove it.

In All my Friends are Psycho you become the psychologist and use original designed Rorschach cards to find out just how demented and gross your friends really are.

The Rorschach card deck is set in the middle face down. Flip the same number of cards that you have players, face up.

Without touching the cards, each player chooses an image to analyze keeping their interpretation a secret.

The psychologist picks up the cards and one by one asks each player what they saw. The psychologist has to match the player's interpretation with the correct card.

If the psychologist guesses correctly, both the player and psychologist gets 1 sanity point. If not, they score 1 psycho point.

Each player takes turns being the psychologist. After this the sanity and psycho points are added up. The player that has the closest number of sanity and psycho points (balances out) wins.

The game comes with 27 Rorschach cards and requires a genuine, original (neither genuine nor original) pad and pen.

In Medieval Might, two generals are pitted against each other in a battle. Each leads their army against each other to become the supreme commander.

Players take turns placing their units, represented by cards, on the battlefield. Each card builds up the strength of their forces, and use tactics to weaken their opponent's forces.

Use your knights and banner-men to greatly increase your strength, while deploying your scouts to gain an advantage over your opponent. If they start to take the lead, use your marksman to eliminate high value targets or ambush their forces to reduce their effectiveness.

The army with the higher value at the end of that round is the victor of that round. The game ends when one player loses two rounds, and the winner is crowned the supreme commander

MATCH! is an abstract family game in where you compete to build chains out of matches.

Search simultaneously for matching cards, which use the Stroop effect, a scientific principle that creates interference in the player's reaction time.

Don't let the cards manipulate you as you build the most chains of cards before all the matches are gone.

The player that makes the most matches wins.

Download Print & Play on:
http://www.trickzbunny.com/match.html

item.description:
There's a house filled with hungry zombies and your team is in the middle of it!!!

Around each corner there are different terrors. Super fast zombies, giant zombies and viscous stalkers are the least of your worries.

Mad House is a nail biting card strategy game for up to 5 players. It features a unique Noise Tracking mechanic; if you're team makes too much noise they will be attacked by horde of zombies!

The only way to survive is to keep everyone alive. Kill the required number of zombies to escape this Nightmare ...

Can you escape the Mad House?!

Wormhole! is a space themed board game for up to 8 players that turns the traditional rules of game play inside out. Everyone starts out at the edge of the board on a spiral track. Every turn you roll the dice, move closer to doom and draw a card. That card may be good, it may be bad, but it will certainly be unpleasant for someone. Red event cards go into effect immediately and may move you forward or back, swap you with the nearest ship or even make you take another turn. Blue mass cards are...mass cards. Mass is also the most common card type in the deck and comes in 25, 50, 75, and 100 unit variants. Mass is bad, because for every 100 mass you accumulate you have to roll another die on your turn. So if you’ve got 300 mass sitting in front of you, you’re rolling 4 dice every turn (that's your original die plus 3 more). And that’s just not going to end well. Green action cards are like the red event cards, but you can hold onto them and use them at your discretion. Use one to send your highest mass card to the person behind you...or if you happen to be that person behind you can use a different one to dodge that mass and let it keep on heading back. There’s even an action card that will let you skip your own turn! When a player inevitably reaches the center of the wormhole, they are out. Flung into the deepest recesses of time and space most likely. When that happens, they mix up their remaining action cards with their mass cards and each remaining player takes one at random (going in order along the track). Play continues until only one player is left on the board, allowing them to safely escape the wormhole and making them the winner.

Crop Circles is an abstract puzzle game for 2-6 players. Taking the role of aliens warning Earthlings of impending doom, players etch glyphs into crop fields with their spaceships, according to changing rules about adjacency between glyph shapes and glyph shading in order to score points for effectively following the rules set forth by the Intergalactic Communications Council.

Each turn, a player places any number of glyph tiles from behind their screen onto the board in an unbroken straight line, connected to glyph tiles that are already on the board. That player scores points for the sum of the values of only the glyphs played (affected by on-board multiplier squares) multiplied by the number of glyph tiles already on the board that were adjacent to their play. Thus, a long string of glyph tiles played parallel to a previous play can net massive points, so players must balance taking advantage of opportunities for huge points with preventing such opportunities for other players. Finally, that player then draws exactly three new glyph tiles either among five face-up glyph tiles next to the play area or from the bag of remaining glyph tiles, regardless of how many they played on their turn, as long as they played at least one glyph.

Glyphs come in four shapes (circles, squares, triangles, and stars) and four shadings (empty, solid, striped, and crossed). Each shading is permitted only to certain shapes, and when a player places glyph tiles on the board, they must satisfy the requirements of both the glyphs being places and the glyphs they are playing adjacent to. The more complex a shading, the more difficult it is to place on the board and the more points it is worth: empty glyphs have no restrictions about what shapes they may be placed adjacent to and are worth only one point; solid glyphs may be adjacent to only three of the four shapes and are worth two points; striped glyphs may be adjacent to only two of four shapes and are worth three points; and crossed glyphs may be adjacent only to a single shape and is worth four points! However, the four active rule cards that determine these permitted adjacencies will get replaced throughout a game, providing new opportunities to play glyphs. Players must plan ahead, acquire useful glyphs, and play them on the most opportune turns.

link.value: 植民地戦争+α (Shokuminchi Sensou Plus Alpha)
植民地戦争+α (Shokuminchi Sensou Plus Alpha)

item.description:
The publisher of KUSUKUMA is Lycée Classique Echternach. Kusukuma is the result of a student game development class (main game idea by Charel Bintz) under the guidance of Dennis Kirps (teacher) and the help of Christian Kruchten (prototype development). The class itself was originated by professor Carmen Schares.

The objective of the game is to push the opponent off the board by cleverly pushing the Kusukuma discs, so that the final player keeps at least one Kusukuma disc of his own on the board. However, as the die determines the colour of the next move, a player might have to push his own disc(s) off the board. The question arises: “Who will be left?”

PLAY
The active player throws the die and chooses exactly one of the following three moves:

1. If one of the four colours is cast, the player has to move one of the discs corresponding to the cast colour by exactly one square horizontally or vertically (not diagonally), even if said colour does not correspond to his own! 
2. If the joker is cast, the player can push any disc, his own, his opponent’s or even the joker.
3. If the blank side is cast, the player cannot make a move, and it is the next player’s turn.

END OF GAME AND WINNER
The game is over when:

 there is only one disc or discs of the same colour left on the game-board. The player representing this colour wins.
 there is only the joker left on the game-board. In this case everybody wins.
 in a game of two or three players, there are only neutral discs left on the game-board. In this case there is no winner.

The Speed-puzzle game.

One who puts the most pieces in to the game, wins.
Players build the same puzzle with their own pieces.

Vauhdikas palapelikilpa!

Ett fartfyllt pusselrace!

Leppisleikki ("Ladybird") is a fun and active game for the entire family that develops motor skills as well as balance and control. In the Ladybird game, players carry out various active tasks together with ladybird. Players are rewarded for successful tasks with the ladybird advancing upwards towards the flower on the stem and winning.

Alien Worlds offers a set of simple, fast-paced rules that even young children (5+) will understand and enjoy.

Alien Worlds is an introductory wargame that pits two teams of six characters against each other across the tabletop. Players can customise their teams to find the right balance of abilities to match their playing style.

The rules include three ways to play - a straightforward skirmish, a retrieval mission and a "High Ground" scenario, adding extra replay value. The winner is the first to meet his objective, or the last with characters still standing.

A handful of miniatures, a couple of six-sided dice and a bit of imagination are all that's required to enjoy Alien Worlds.

It is 1944, eastern front was falling into its ,ost dangerous phase. With overwhelming military power soviet forces have penetrated german front lines in various places succeeded in surroundING a German Corp . The Germans have assembled a handful of armored units to rescue the besieged german troops.

Kiss my ass is a card game on tactical combat in the eastern front 1944. One player plays the Germans and the other the ussr.

The game has 110 cards, 6 dice an English and japanese language rules manuals..The game is based on Motofumi Kobayashi's classic manga Black Knight
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motofumi_Kobayashi

1st edition was published by Tenkafubu.

item.description:
The Battle of Belleau Wood is one of the most famous engagements in the long and storied history of the United States Marine Corps. Weeks of brutal combat earned them the grudging respect of the vanquished Germans, who called them Teufelhunde - Devil Dogs.

IN THE TRENCHES (ITT) system makes its Tiny Battle debut with three scenarios drawn from this exciting battle. Designed by John Gorkowski, this series enables players to game historically accurate simulations of tactical operations from the Great War. ITT challenges players to move and fight with company-level formations made of separate platoon-sized units during five minute, impulsed-based turns. The historically accurate maps are scaled to 100 yards per hex. This approach recreates WWI command and control problems and inspire historically accurate play without forcing decisions.

This set includes all the counters you’ll need to play these scenarios, PLUS all the status markers and administrative counters you’ll need to play any expansion.

Includes:

 176 counters to manouevre
 Three 8.5x11-inch maps
 1 rulebook to rifle through
 1 Player Aid Card and Scenario Card
 1 Game Turn Track




(source: Tiny Battle Publishing website)

link.value: In the Trenches: Coup de Grace
In the Trenches: Devil Dogs 2 Faith & Sacrifice
In the Trenches: Through Fire and Flames

item.description:
Sector Prime is a fast paced, light 4X board game using a balanced dice rolling mechanic that avoids a runaway winner and also keeps the game exciting and balanced right to the end. The unique design of the tiles provides a completely new game board each time, requiring players to adapt the strategies each time they play!

Each player represents a mining faction seeking to control the mining rights to the sector. You need to control enough planetary systems to mine the needed materials to complete the construction of your Mining Station
 In each turn there are 3 phases:

(1) Explore. 
By a roll of the dice move your mining drones to new planet tiles.

(2) Expand or Exterminate. 
You must choose to either invade and attack another mining faction OR to build defenses, new routes of exploration or a section of your Station thus bringing you one step closer to victory.

(3) Exploit.
In this phase you gather the results of your mining operations. You can simply gather the minimum OR you can gamble by pushing your drones produce double. Be careful, because this isn't always successful.

The first player to complete construction of their Station wins the game!

item.description: Played on a wooden board, there are three ways to win this abstract-strategy game: Get three circular pieces of your color in a row in either ascending or descending order; get the same sized pieces in a row; or get three concentric pieces in the same space.

item.description:
From the creator of the original "Name Game" comes this new edition that will leave the family guessing!

Designed for younger and older players. Draw a card and give creative descriptions and clues... Try to get your team to guess as many names as possible before the timer runs out.

link.value: Name Game: The Celebrity Guessing Game

item.description:
Battle on the high seas or in the crowded streets of the Spanish Main as a Pirate, Pirate Hunter or a simple Merchant in this minatures game!

Using the Chain Reaction System found in all of Two Hour Wargames, you field a group of characters with very simple stats: Reputation and Weapons. Activation rolls tell you when you are able to go (higher rolls go first, but only activate higher Reputation groups) and then you may move and fire/charge. That's it!

Of course, being the reaction system, the other figures on the board won't be sitting and waiting for you to finish in a IGO-UGO fashion, but will react to your moves using a series of tables that may have them running from you, drawing pistols and firing, or charging into combat swords shining!

Be the last pirate standing and win!
Or play a campaign and retire with the most gold to win!

Rules to adventure ashore?Check!
Big Land Battles to sack Panama? Check!
Ship combat with boarding actions? Check!
Big Sea Battles to fight fleets? Check!
Treasure maps and buried treasure? Check!

name.value: The Struggle for Portugal: Peninsular War III, 1810-11
The Struggle for Portugal: Peninsular War III, 1810-11

item.description:
From the publisher:

The Struggle for Portugal - Peninsular War III contains four battles in Portugal and Spain during 1811: Barrosa, Fuentes de Oñoro, and Albuera.

The Struggle for Portugal - Peninsular War III is one of the games from OSG's The Library of Napoleonic Battles series. Details on the series are below, as all the games share a common rules set and game system.

BATTLES SIMULATED

Barrosa, 5 March 1811
A reduction in the besieging forces gave the garrison of Cadiz an opportunity to break out. Loading on to naval transports, they debarked at Tarifa and moved to engage the siege lines from the rear. The French, under the command of Marshal Victor, placed one division on the road to Cadiz, while his two remaining divisions fell on the single Anglo-Portuguese division under Sir Thomas Graham. Following a fierce battle, the British succeeded in routing the French but could not prevent their reoccupying their siege lines.

Fuentes de Onoro, 3 - 5 May 1811
Wellington first secured Portugal and then set about re-taking the fortified frontier cities of Almeida, Badajoz, and Ciudad Rodrigo. Whilst Wellington besieged Almeida, Massena reformed his battered army and marched to relieve the French garrison in the city. Wellington chose to check the relief attempt at the small village of Fuentes de Oñoro.

La Albuera 16 May 1811
Wellesley sent Sir William Beresford to retake the border town of Badajoz. Soult rapidly gathered a new army from Andalusia and, joining with the troops retreating before Beresford, he marched to relieve the siege. With the Spanish army under General Joaquin Blake approaching, he planned to turn Beresford's flank and interpose his army between his position and the Spaniards. However, the Spaniards had already linked up with the Anglo-Portuguese corps, and his 24,000 troops now faced a combined Allied army 35,000 strong. The opposing armies met at the village of Albuera. Both sides suffered heavily in the ensuing struggle and the French eventually withdrew on 18 May.

DESCRIPTION

The Library of Napoleonic Battles - formerly known as the Napoleon's Last Battles (NLB) Series:


 480 meters per hex, 
 1 hour per turn, 
 400-800 men per strength point. 


Each Approach to Battle game lasts about 22 turns. The Full campaign links the individual battles.

This game brings a whole new experience! Players write down the names of people on the piece hidden in small hose pieces. These people will then be portrayed in three different ways. The game is played in three rounds where all teams meet each other. Fast glossary, loud laughter, tongue-tied, blackout and wild gestures succeed each other in a fast pace! A brand new party game that never gets old!

Stop Nomsters from getting candies.

In the game you and your friend(s), stop the Nomsters from getting candies and other goods by throwing bean-bags at them.

You are a mail deliverer.

You goal is to deliver mails faster than other players.

In this variant edition of Sequence, the poker decks have been replaced by two decks each depicting 42 different breeds of house cat, from the Abyssinian to the Turkish Van. The board has been reduced from 10x10 to 7x12, with no wild corners. The Jacks have been replaced by Purr and Meow cards.

As in traditional Sequence, the object of the game is for one player or team to form a line of five or more consecutive chips, either orthogonally or diagonally. Players take turns drawing and playing cards, using a card from hand to claim one space on the board matching the played card. 2 or 3 players can play; higher player counts are supported via team play.

item.description:
Form on Admiral's Wake is a quick-playing miniatures game of fleet naval battle during the age of sailing warships. It allows for the play of larger naval battles with a small number of players who will each control one or more squadrons of ships. The game is typically played with miniatures on a hex grid.

The game system uses an action deck to determine which ships can activate and what actions they can perform. The action cards have limitations based on a ship's fleet, sail state, wind orientation, crew quality, and damage level. The more favorable the condition and status of a ship, the more cards it will activate on.

One card is flipped each turn and ships that meet the requirements of the card may perform actions as indicated in the instructions. The actions allowed vary by card, but include moving one hex, sideslipping one hex, turning in a hex, and reloading cannons. Once fired, cannons require two actions to reload.

After all actions from the flip of a card are completed, all ships with loaded cannons may fire simultaneously. As a ship takes damage, its status reduces from undamaged to disabled to crippled. As the status changes, the ship will have less chances to activate.

Additional rules cover critical hits, grappling, fires, forts, anchoring, and fire ships.

The game is essentially a modified deck of traditional playing cards, but featuring cartoon parodies of popular rap artists.

Each player is dealt a hand of 12 cards from the deck, and a game lasts 12 rounds. The player to the left of the dealer goes first.

Each round the top card of the deck is revealed, and the color of that card becomes the "trump" color. Each player plays a card from their hand of the trump color if they can. If the player does not have a card in the trump color he may play any card. The round ends when each player has played a card. If trump colored cards have been played, then the highest trump colored card played that round wins. If no trump colored cards were played, then the highest card of any color wins.

The winner of the round scores 10 points. The first player to score 187 points or higher is the winner of the game.

(It should be noted that, since a game only lasts 12 rounds and players only score 10 points for a round, it is impossible to score the required number of points in a game to win)

You are investigating alien ruins on Mars. Just as you are getting ready to take all the artifacts back to your ship, disaster strikes! A meteor storm sweeps across the planet! Your equipment is damaged! Your oxygen is running low! And to top it off the dust kicked up by the meteors has obscured the location of your ship!

What had been days worth of air is now only a few scant hours. You have to make it back to your spaceship - but what about all the artifacts you have already found? Decide what to take and what to leave, but remember, if you take too much, you run out of oxygen faster!

The game is played by moving your character across the barren Martian landscape, exploring tiles, attempting to find any Martian artifacts, more air, and most importantly, your ship. Your spacesuit has three randomly selected abilities that can help your character navigate the hostile terrain. Abilities which come into play when Event cards are drawn after moving.

The player only wins when:

 The player does not run out of air.
 The player finds the spaceship.
 The player has at least one alien artifact upon reaching the spaceship.




The Mars Exploration mission fails if no items from the Martian Ruins make it back to Earth.

This was an entry in the 2014 Solitaire Print and Play Contest. It won first place for:

 Best Large Game
 Best Thematic Game
 Best Greyscale Printed Game

In this game, the player adventures through the Temple of Heryshaf, the Ancient Egyptian god of Primordial Waters. The goal is to reach the apex of the temple - Heryshaf’s Inner Sanctum! But beware! For the temple is filled with traps, and the passageways are winding!

At the start of the game, choose one of the five cards at the base of the pyramid to start the path. Each turn take the token representing your character and move it onto a card. The token may only move to a new card if the room you are in has a path which leads to that card and the card you are moving to has a corresponding path. When you attempt to move to a new card, flip the card over and sees what effects are activated. There are both traps and helper cards you may find inside the temple. You may choose to backtrack, but if you do, one card on the board is discarded, and a new unknown card takes its place - which may help or hinder you later.

The player wins if they make it through the temple, avoiding the traps or disarming the traps, to arrive safely at Heryshaf's Inner Sanctum.

This game tied for first place in the 24 hour contest for September 2014.

name.value: Better Me: The Game of Growth and Friendship

item.description:
Better Me is a new approach to relationships and personal development. It challenges people to take action to improve themselves and their life, and strengthens relationships by helping people understand each other in a deeper and more meaningful way.

The game brings up interesting topics that don't normally come up in daily conversation, allowing players to quickly learn about themselves and their fellow players. And all in an encouraging and fun atmosphere, with no pressure or judgment permitted. When was the last time you told a group of people about a past accomplishment that you're proud of, or had a game challenge you to write a thank you letter to a loved one?

Better Me also harnesses the power of accountability. Any player committing to an action must find an accountability partner to help make sure they follow they follow through on their commitment. Both players write down the action to be taken, and the target completion date on their game sheet. This accountability strategy is key to insuring that players take action and grow.

Players move around the game board and draw cards which prompt all sorts of positive action and discussion. Players race to fulfill each of their five life areas, heart, mind, body, people and tangibles. The game is won by the first player to "fulfill" (3 points) each of the five categories; heart, mind, body, people, and tangibles. Alternatively, the game may be played to a time limit, and if no player has fulfilled all categories by the end of the time limit, the player with the most total points is the winner.

In addition to being played by groups of friends and family, Better Me is also popular with counselors, schools/universities, youth mentoring programs, recovery programs, hospitals, etc.

It's a new and engaging way to improve yourself and your relationships with friends, family, and coworkers, all while having fun!

Yakitori, the famed Japanese street food on skewers, is now a game in which players are skewering tiles, placing dice, and manipulating a fickle market to vie for the most Yen from hungry customers.

In the game, players roll dice, select from actions such as Cooking, Market, and Influence. Food tiles are bought, skewered, and sold at just the right time to net a healthy profit. Clever planning can pay off in this family-friendly game that will also intrigue seasoned gamers looking for a thinky game that integrates theme with mechanisms.

Stramash is a chase game where you have to get your "Laddies" round the board to the safety of your castle. You also need to stop your opponents. You do this by landing on your opponent's Laddie so they have to go back to their start. Remember, they are trying to do the same to you! You use one of the six cards in your hand to decide which move is best for you - is it time to get to safety or to get revenge? You decide.

Be prepared to be ruthless... while you all have loads of fun.

name.value: Kyoui no heya: Geijutsu ni kakusareta allegory

item.description:
English:
This designing of this game was commissioned by the Dutch "Rijksgebouwendienst" (government building service). It is an attempt to make the changing in their organizational structure more transparent through a boardgame. During the game, player collect points by completing projects en cooperatively realizing the construction of a building. Completing projects is accomplished by negotiating with other players for the right "people". The game contains 6 types of people, each with their own special skills, represented by game chips.

Note: The game was published in order of a department of the Dutch government and was therefore only published in Dutch.

Dutch:
Dit spel is ontworpen in opdracht van de Rijksgebouwendienst. Het is een poging om het het kantelen van haar organisatie inzichtelijk maken middels een bordspel. In het spel moeten de spelers punten verdienen door projecten uit te voeren én gezamenlijk een gebouw te realiseren. Het uitvoeren van een project gebeurt door te onderhandelen met de andere spelers over de juiste mensen die moeten worden ingezet. Het spel bevat 6 type mensen, met verschillende capaciteiten, vertegenwoordigd door spel fiches.

Maximum Apocalypse is a cooperative roguelike adventure game for 1-6 players. In Maximum Apocalypse, civilization has already fallen. The players are survivors of the apocalypse whose mission is to survive the hostile landscape.

The game map is randomly generated and different every time that you play. On each turn, a player can use up to four actions to explore the map, play cards, equip weapons, scavenge for resources, draw cards or battle off monsters.

Picking a unique survivor class within the group, players must plan their strategy and work together while leaning on their survivor’s strengths in order to defeat monsters and avoid starvation. For example, the Fireman is deadly up close with his ax and can easily chop down monsters; meanwhile the stealthy Hunter is great at scouting the map and avoiding traps — but roaming monsters are gathering quickly and time is running out. If you are overwhelmed by monsters or die of starvation, the players lose. If they can find enough gas and get it back to their van to escape, they all win and live to play another scenario.

item.description:
You are the captain of a crew of workers, abandoned by your superiors on the planet Rhodon V, which you once mined for resources. Now, a cargo ship has crash landed nearby and its crew has offered a ride off of the planet to anyone able to repair their ship – but you aren't the only one to respond to the distress beacon. Will you be the first player to collect all of the Repair Parts to fix the cargo ship and escape the planet?

The goal of Scrap is to be the first player to collect three different Repair Parts and deliver them back to the Start Area. Repair Parts can be collected by passing over specific spaces on the board or by looting them from your opponents after defeating them in battle.

Each player operates a unique vehicle, monstrous tank-like machines that have been constructed from salvaged mining and military equipment. Each vehicle starts with a special ability, different stats, and a set amount of upgrade slots. As players traverse the board, they will collect Resource Cards through different means, which are used to build upgrades, collect Unique Upgrades, trigger Events, and more.

A high quality deck of playing cards made up of letters. With it, you can play hundreds of word games and card games. Instead of numbers, sets and runs, you use letters and make words.

Letter Playing Cards are for all ages. Whether you’re just starting out learning your letters and words in pre-school, or a scholar of the English language, fascinated by words. Whether you're a backpacker travelling light and meeting new friends, or a parent with too much luggage.

It's a whole new dimension on the phrase ‘Let’s have a game of cards’.

Here’s the short list of some of the more popular games you can play with Letter Playing Cards.

Word Poker; Texas Spell ‘Em; Rummy / Gin Rummy; Brag (3,4, 5 card or 9 card!); Patience / solo games; Hangman; Snaffle - the letter grab game; Old Maid; Murder (or Mafia); Word Black Jack; Letter Cheat; Word Speed or Spit; Go Fish; Hearts; Indian Word Poker; Moogle; Spoons; Letter Whist; Anagrams; Crosswords; Ghost; Flash Cards, Spelling tests, Word Bridge.

In the distant past, a starship from a faraway world appeared in the sky. Damaged in battle, the craft broke apart and traced lines of fire across the horizon. These falling stars crashed to the surface, and in the ages to come, became enshrined in legends as the Lost Legacy. Discover where the Lost Legacy can be found and win the game!

Lost Legacy: Orb of Prophecy can be played independently or mixed together with other Lost Legacy sets to create a unique custom set. This version was released at AEG Big Game Night at GenCON 2015 and won't be sold for retail.

As for how to play, Lost Legacy is a game of risk, deduction, and luck for 2–4 players. You start the game with one card in hand from a deck of sixteen cards. On a turn, you do the following:


 Draw: Draw the top card from the deck and add it to your hand.
 Play: Choose one of the two cards in hand to play and place it face up in front of you.
 Effect: Carry out the played card's effect, after which the card is considered as discarded.
 End: Throughout gameplay you're trying to eliminate other players or uncover the location of the "Lost Legacy" card; this card might also be in the "Ruins", a location that holds one card at the start of the game and possibly acquires more cards during play. When someone discovers the Lost Legacy, the game ends, everyone tallies the value of the cards they've played and the card left in hand, and whoever has the highest total wins.
 


By combining different Lost Legacy sets (while keeping only a single Lost Legacy card in play), up to six players can compete at the same time.

link.value: Lost Legacy: Fourth Chronicle – The Werewolf & Undying Heart
Lost Legacy: Second Chronicle – Vorpal Sword & Whitegold Spire
Lost Legacy: Third Chronicle – Sacred Grail & Staff of Dragons
Lost Legacy: Binbo Tantei to Inbo no Shiro

name.value: 世界イセキ発見 (Discovery of World Ruins)

item.description: In ä¸–ç•Œã‚¤ã‚»ã‚­ç™ºè¦‹ (Discovery of World Ruins), one player represents ancient people and places ruins secretly somewhere in a 5x5 grid. The other players are archaeologists and need to uncover the location of these ruins through reasoning and hints from the lost ancient people.

name.value: The Looney Tunes Show Run Tweety Run Game

item.description: Basic spin and move game with Sylvester chasing Tweety around the board. Each player gets a Sylvester mover and tries to land on the Tweety mover. If the spinner lands on Run Tweety Run, Tweety moves from one birdcage to another. The first Sylvester to land on Tweety three times wins.

1WW: The First World War is a low complexity, highly abstracted, two-player game of the entire First World War in Europe that lasted from 1914-1918. The game is played on a single tabloid-sized map, and 140 half-inch playing pieces.

This mini-game is included in Issue #2 of Counterfact magazine.

Components:
One rulebook
One 11"x17" map
140 double-sided die-cut counters
One six-sided die is required to play (not included)

GG is based on the idea of having a card game that is as easy as learning rock-paper-scissors, but more based on strategy, memory and deception.

Each player has an identical 32-deck of cards. Players use these cards to make 4 piles of 8 cards each to challenge each other.

Instead of challenging an opponent, strategy cards can be played.

The goal is to eliminate the rivals by attaining their GG cards.

item.description:
The game consists of two packs of 30 cards. Each card has a picture on one side and a description on the other.
 One pack of cards is spread out picture side up so that all pictures can be seen. The other pack is stacked picture side up. The game starts by turning over the top card of the stack so that the descritipion can be read. Somewhere amongst the pictures showing is the item matching this description but finding the match may not be as easy as it seems as the pictures have been chosen so as to appear to be something else and a little imagination may be needed to make the match. Whoever makes the match first takes both cards and then the next stack card is turned over and a new match has to be found. When all cards in the stack have been used, whoever has the most cards in the winner. The game rules state that it is for two players or teams but clearly any number can play.

Highwaymen is a 2-4 player tabletop game in which the Players take on the roles of a group of Highwaymen attempting to rob a coach travelling through a dangerous forest trail.

Players must work together to steal the gold from the coach but must be wary that at any moments their comrades could turn against them!

The game is played in 2 phases, firstly, the players take it in turn to take their actions, afterwards the Coach and Escorts will take their turn. A Player's turn can be taken in one of two ways, Players can either fire their pistols, or attempt to steal gold from another Player. If the player chooses to shoot, they shoot their pistols twice at the Escorts or the Coach, move up to 3D6 spaces, then shoot twice more. If the Player tries to steal, they roll 3D6 movement, and can attempt to steal from the first Player they come into contact with.

If an Escort takes damage it is removed from the board and if the Coach takes damage then it will drop coins. The Players can move over the Coins to add them to their collection, the winner of the game is the Player with the most coins at the end of the Game. The game ends when either the Coach leaves the woods (after 8 turns) or the Players destroy the Coach (when it has taken 20 hits).

Aim of the game: to help Barbie fill her wardrobe with new fashion accessories. Contents: Game board, 36 illustrated discs
4 Barbie playing pieces, 4 plastic bases, 2 handbag cards, 1 die & Game rules.

This is a combination Memory game & board game. Players start on the Barbie that matches their playing piece on the corner of the playing board. The discs of accessories are placed upside down in the middle of the board. Players roll & move around the board, turning over a disc to try to match the accessory they land on. If it matches, they keep it. If not, play passes to next player. If they land on a handbag square, they get one of the two handbags. If they land on a player square, they get to take a handbag from one of the other players. In order to win, they must get each accessory, get a handbag and return to their Barbie square.

Game published in Brazil in the 70's (probably 1970) by ABAE - Associação Brasileira de Alimentação Escolar (Brazilian Association for Nutrition in School) in order to collect funds for its activities.
It's a football game in which the ball is moved according to the result of a die roll. According to the rules, the match's duration is 10 minutes divided in two 5-minute halves.

item.description: This game was published in Bugs Bunny's Trick 'n' Treat Halloween Fun #3 in 1955 by Dell. Cicero is Porky Pig's nephew. This is basically a board game version of the traditional party game where players try to bite an apple hanging from a string. The players race to be the first to finish "eating" their apples. Each player gets an illustration of an apple which is cut into 11 pieces. They then take turns drawing chits from a box; when the chit shows an apple, the player can remove a piece of their apple. If the chit shows a jack o'lantern, they've missed the apple and the game-play goes back to the other player.

The fun spreads like wildfire with UNO Disney Planes: Fire & Rescue! Classic UNO rules apply, but the addition of a special rule and 4 extra cards gives players a chance to experience all new game changing moments! When you play a Water Drop Card, each blue card in your hand acts like water: empty them ALL into the discard pile like water from your tanks putting out a fire. Then you get to choose the next color to resume play! Fans of the film will recognize their favorite characters—like Dusty Crophopper, Skipper Riley and Blade Ranger—all of which are featured in true-to-movie detail on the cards they play. And do not forget to yell "UNO" when you only have one card left! Includes 112 cards and instructions.

Published by Standard Comics in "Santa's Christmas Comics" in December, 1952. Simple race game where you use chits instead of dice to determine moves. Goal is to be the first to reach the end. Board shows several of Standard's funny animal characters in Christmas scenes, the most well-known being Supermouse, Spotty the Pup, and Buster Bunny, as they each had their own titles.

Spoilers is a party-trivia game with movie questions and bluffing mechanisms.

The player taking the spoiler role (a different one each turn) makes a question about what happens in a particular movie and gives three possible answers (A, B, C). The Spoiler knows the right answer and earns points when the other players answer incorrectly and loses points when they get it right. Thus, the Spoiler will try to mislead them (and everyone knows that). Everyone takes the role of Spoiler three times, then the player with the most points wins.

•••

Party Game con preguntas de cine y mecánicas de faroleo.

El jugador que toma el rol de Spoiler (uno diferente en cada turno) hace una pregunta acerca de lo que sucede en una película en particular y da tres respuestas posibles (A, B, C). El jugador Spoiler sabe cuál la respuesta correcta, pero sólo ganará puntos cuando el resto de jugadores fallen y perderá puntos cuando acierten, por lo que tratará de despistarlos (y todo el mundo lo sabe).

La partida dura tres rondas (cada jugador Spoiler hará 3 preguntas) y el jugador con más puntos al final, gana.

The players place their Othello-style tokens in a 10 x 10 grid, shuffle the cards and place them in a pile. The players then take turns drawing cards, which give instructions about flipping tokens over. A player's first goal is to change the color of an entire column of 10 tokens into their color. This column is then locked to the end of the game. The player with the most columns locked in their color is the winner. The game comes with 100 wooden tokens and 50 cards.
